thread.title: Utah's usual trength —special teams — is Utes' weakness in victory over ASU
thread.title_full: Utah's usual trength —special teams — is Utes' weakness in victory over ASU | Deseret News

author: Amy Donaldson
title: Utah's usual trength —special teams — is Utes' weakness in victory over ASU
text:
Special teams has been outstanding for Utah this season, but Saturday night the unit was the team's weakness.
Upcoming Games Utah Football Utah Utah @ USC Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum, Los Angeles Oct. 24, 5:30 p.m. 5 Days 23 Hrs 27 Mins 58 Secs More Coverage Rock: With the Utes, it's always going to tie to Wilson Utes report card vs. Arizona State Utes remain unbeaten with 34-18 win over Arizona State Utes go to the air with Wilson on rainy night SALT LAKE CITY — Utah’s special teams play has been so dynamic this season that the unit overlooked on many teams has become this team’s shining star.
Saturday night that star stumbled.
With uncharacteristic mistakes and miscues, special teams errors nearly cost Utah its first win against Arizona State since 1976.
“Special teams was atrocious,” said Utah head coach Kyle Whittingham after Utah defeated the Sun Devils 34-18. “Almost lost the game single-handedly special teams-wise. That’s not like us. We’ve got to get that fixed. We probably gave up 15 points on special teams.”
Thankfully, what Utah’s special teams gave away, the Ute defense wrestled back.
“Our defense didn’t let them into the end zone,” Whittingham said. “Bottom line, our defense gave up nothing. Proud of them. They were collectively the player of the game for us.”
The trouble began when Utes gave up a 100-yard kickoff return to Tim White just four seconds after they scored their first touchdown.
When the subsequent drive stalled, Tom Hackett booted a punt 56 yards, but a holding penalty forced him to make the kick again. ASU’s De’Chavon Hayes looked like he was going to get all the way into the end zone until Hackett brought him down on the 13-yard line. That led to Zane Gonzalez' first of three field goals, and ASU’s first lead, 10-7.
The worst of the disappointing plays came in the third quarter right after Utah’s defense forced ASU to settle for a field goal. With a 14-13 lead, freshman Britain Covey caught the kickoff deep in the end zone and then turned and threw what was later ruled an illegal forward pass that fell short of its intended receiver, Bubba Poole. It was ruled a safety, and the Sun Devils took a 15-14 lead.
“The plan was, I catch it deep, fake like I’m going to run up, stop right before the goal line and then throw a backwards pass to Bubba and he goes,” Covey said. “It worked in practice; that was a really bad throw.”
Covey said he was relieved his teammates rallied from the mistake.
“I really am overwhelmed,” he said. “Not as much for me and how we finished, but it’s when I came off the sideline after that stupid play, I didn’t hear one negative thing from any one of my teammates. I just appreciated that.” Linebacker and team captain Gionni Paul said earlier in the postgame press conference that Saturday night’s victory was a team effort.
“It’s a little frustrating for sure, because (special teams) is something we pride ourselves on here at Utah,” Covey said. “It’s nothing we can’t fix. I know we’re going to evaluate things. It was tough tonight to have that be the weakness.”
